title: Letter: Over-50s can do more than plug the labour gap
text:
As we see the proportion of workers over 50 in hospitality roles increasing in the UK (“Bars and restaurants turn to over-50s to plug labour gap”, Report, October 10), I agree with the stance taken by Kathy Dyball, the director at Caterer.com whom you quote, that employers taking on older candidates is a step in the right direction.

However, where she argues that more roles “that can suit people of any working age” need to be highlighted, I find myself in disagreement. Isn't the onus on employers to make jobs with them more accommodating to an ageing workforce?

Despite what McDonald's adverts may suggest, many older people are not “retiring types”. However, ageist working practices lead many over-50s to either give up looking for new opportunities or retire, disillusioned, from jobs they once enjoyed.

Employers have a significant opportunity now to not just lure older people back to the labour market, but make people want to stay in work well past the age of 50 by creating a culture that celebrates age diversity. For example, recruiters should give equal weighting to skills and experience, so older candidates who need training aren't discounted. Multi-generational collaboration within the workplace, through projects and older employees training the younger, will also help older workers to contribute and feel fulfilled by their roles.

Rather than simply plugging labour gaps, employers can make a change that will benefit the over-50s, their employers and generations to come. When we are in a cost of living crisis that's only being made worse by a tightened labour market, why not run with this opportunity?

Steve Butler
Chief Executive, Punter Southall Aspire, London WC2, UK
